app_desc.message: Auto Highlight is text highlighter with RegExp support

toolbar_click_new_tab.message: Always open in New tab - when clicking toolbar icon

temporal_rule_helper.message: Temporal rule - will be deleted after restarting browser

across_elements_help.message: Search for text across neighbor html elements

storage_safari_1.message: Safari currently doesn't support automatic data synchronization.

storage_safari_2.message: To transfer (or backup) your highlight rules, use the "Import / Export" feature.

storage_info_1.message: Your rules are stored using secure $1 Sync that will synchronize your rules between all your devices (if you are logged in to the same account).

storage_info_2.message: This cloud storage can store 100 KB of data and up to 500 highlight rules.

storage_info_3.message: You can also export (backup) your rules to a file using "Import / Export" feature and then import it on other devices.

empty_name_helper.message: Leave empty to use "Highlighted text" as name

faq_1.message: How to quickly highlight word on current page?

faq_1a.message: Use context menu - select text / right click / "Auto Highlight". If you right click on a page (without selecting text) you can apply existing rules to current page.

faq_2.message: I want to highlight multiple words, do I need to create new rule for each word separately?

faq_2a.message: No, just check the "Each word" checkbox. Then each word will be highlighted separately.

faq_3a.message: Also known as Regular expression, it's a sequence of characters that define a search pattern. It's a complicated construct that allows complex highlighting of elements with some similar pattern. For example prices, dates, phone numbers, etc...

faq_4.message: Can you show me some RegExp examples?

faq_5a.message: "$1$" highlights dollar sign. The backslash is needed here because dollar has a special meaning in RegExp.

faq_5c.message: "$1$" means repeat one or more times. When placed after digit selector $2$, it means one or more digits.

faq_5d.message: "$1$" highlights dot. The backslash is again needed because dot symbol alone means any single character in RegExp.

faq_5e.message: "$1$" means zero or one time. When placed after brackets $2$, it means whatever is inside those brackets is optional (can be there, or not). We use it for the decimal part of the number which is optional.

exact_match_title.message: Match only full words, not partial text inside a word
